text: Share this article Share Making her way outside, the fence spun to reveal mirrored screens, as she was joined on stage by Skip Marley, grandson of the late reggae great, Bob. Despite claiming on the red carpet earlier in the night that her performance would be 'mostly me' and not her usual troupe of backing dancers, that proved not to be the case as the house and fences broke apart to reveal exactly that. White out: The 32-year-old rocked a white pant suit and her new blonde look. On her right arm she wore arm armband which read: 'Resist' Don't fence me in: She opened the catchy track beside a house surrounded by a white picket fence Decoration: 'Are we crazy? Living our lives through a lens,' she sang 'Trapped in our white picket fence like ornaments.' 'No hate!' Katy roared at the end of the song, and the fence reunited to display the wording of the United States constitution, and its famous opening: 'We the people'. It's no secret Katy is unhappier than most with the current Administration: she was one of the most vocal campaigners among Hillary Clinton's celeb supporters. Ahead of the performance, she had told E! News it would be 'definitely unlike anything I’ve ever done'. 'Usually there’s a lot of dancers and things but it’s mostly just me,' she said. 'But it’s a different just me… just pay close attention to the narrative.' Katy also had plenty to say in the red carpet earlier in the evening — and not all of it went down too well. Elaborate: Making her way outside, the fence spun to reveal mirrored screens Solo: On the red carpet earlier in the night she claimed her performance would be 'mostly me' and not her usual troupe of backing dancers However: That proved not to be the case as the house and fences broke apart to reveala team of backup dancers First she swore live on TV, even having her lips blurred out by a quick reacting CBS. 'Sorry, I'm live. I still couldn't stop swearing. Sorry mom and dad,' she said. And that wasn't her only eyebrow-raising moment - with fans jumping on a comment made by Katy that appeared to 'throw shade' at Britney Spears. Skip a generation: She was joined on stage by Skip Marley, grandson of the late reggae great, Bob Just love: 'No hate!' Katy roared at the end of the song Statement: The fence reunited to display the wording of the United States constitution, and its famous opening: 'We the people' Katy, who wore an attention-grabbing Tom Ford dress, had been explaining the long gap since her last album, 2014's Prism. 'There was a pause in the music for a little while,' queried E!'s Ryan Seacrest. Replied Katy: 'Yeah that's called taking care of your mental health.' 'How'd that go?' he asked, leading to Katy's apparent reference to Britney. 'Fantastic! And I haven't shaved my head yet,' she joked. New look: Ahead of the performance, she had told E!
